newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Ringgit rebounds as offshore parties sell dollar.
newsitem.headline: Ringgit rebounds as offshore parties sell dollar.

text.p: The ringgit rebounded against the dollar as the market discounted worries about the possibility of a U.S. rate hike, dealers said.
They said dollar/ringgit sales by offshore players broke a dollar-support level at 2.4850. "There was heavy offshore selling," said a Malaysian bank dealer.
He said the next strong support for dollar/ringgit was at 2.4780.
The dollar's weakness was also linked to its retreat against the yen in Tokyo, dealers said. "The yen has came off," said another dealer.
Research house MMS International said there was also market talk the dollar/ringgit fall was due to a corporate samurai bond issue of $400 million.
The ringgit had started on a weak note following overnight dollar gains after comments by U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan which hinted of an interest rate hike.
At 0900 GMT, the ringgit was at 2.4833/43 per dollar against 2.4810/20 at the end of Kuala Lumpur trading on Wednesday.
